One of the major reasons George W. Bush was one of the worst presidents in American history was his sheer incompetence. He lied us into an unjustified war in Iraq, but the main reason he left office in disgrace was the ineptitude with which that war was conducted. At a cost to the taxpayers of $5 trillion, it dragged on for almost a decade and destroyed many thousands of lives. If the premature declaration of "Mission Accomplished" had been true, Bush, Cheney and the other GOP warmongers might have gotten away with it.

The most recent Republican presidential administration was also marked by incompetence in economic policy. Bush inherited a budget surplus from Bill Clinton, and he exited office with the economy in ruins.

Barack Obama has spent most of his time in office cleaning up messes incompetent Republicans created.

By focusing resentment on gays, Blacks, Mexicans, "Arabs" - meaning anyone with a brown skin and an accent who ISN'T Mexican - and "socialists," they are effectively distracting the working class from recognizing their real exploiters.

If they elect a Senate majority next year, they will not only abolish the EPA, but muzzle the SEC, the FDA and any other agency that deals with the health, welfare or financial security of regular people. Sorry, Dr. Krugman, but you are too kind to the R's.

Today's Republicans are not bunglers. Quite the contrary. To them, the absence of any realistic policy initiatives that might address the nation's real problems is their strength, not weakness. In fact the nation's problems, the practical ones you mention, are not even theirs . They are ours, and we don't figure into their plans.

Republicans are not interested in solving environmental, social justice or economic problems because their interest is solely in serving their masters, the plutocrats who have no stake in the country's future. Those masters are not Americans in the traditional sense, that is, dreamers of and supporters of the American dream, where anyone and everyone who works hard enough has an equal chance to succeed. The Republican masters are not interested in equality. In fact, equality is their enemy number one.

That is why their policies (and they do have them) are directed at targets that seem so off center to most of us: They want taxes cut for the rich, corporate taxes slashed, environmental regulations eviscerated, the right to vote restricted, Social Security, Medicare and now the ACA weakened and everything privatized into profit centers for the few.

No, the R's may look silly, but they are not bungling. They don't govern well precisely because they don't want government to work well.

In fact, if it doesn't work for their own selfish ends, they don't want any government at all, .

"Opiate" has been misused by Max (to be fair, also by Marx!) to mean any calming substance to which one can become addicted or dependent or develop a higher tolerance for a threshhold effect. 12-step programs need to stop referring to anything tangible upon which one becomes dependent or even addicted as an "opiate." An "opiate" is a substance that is a natural derivative of opium (heroin, morphine, codeine); an "opioid" is a wholly synthetic version thereof (hydrocodone, oxycodone, hydromorphone, oxymorphone).

Benzodiazepines, melatonin agonists, sedating antihistamines (e.g., diphenydramine, aka Benadryl), anti-nauseants such as dimenhydrinate (Dramamine), scopolamine, alcohol (which paradoxically causes but then truncates sleep), and even melatonin and herbs such as kava kava and valerian root are all soporifics upon whom people can become dependent for sleep--but they are NOT "opiates!" Neither are non-soporifics to which people can become habituated or even "addicted" for good or ill: OTC painkillers (acetaminophen or NSAIDs), caffeine, chocolate, sugar/starch, gambling, risky behaviors, sex, shopping, TV, music, religion, power, attention, adulation, the Internet, etc.

Twelve-step programs are extremely valuable in the management of addiction, but when they incorrectly use medical terminology they undermine their credibility in the eyes of both the scientific community and substance abusers in denial about their addictions.

I work with a guy who takes shots of coffee, in these small cups, throughout the day, and I can see that he has energy, but it is a kind of highly-wired energy that does not seem healthy in the long run.  Another guy I used to work with would complain about major headaches on the weekends, due to caffeine withdrawal, from drinking a lot of coffee during the weekday.  I ask myself, why must we be so high on coffee, just to put in eight hours or so at work? Drinking coffee in the morning is a big problem that many fail to acknowledge as they get older. I gave it up and do not miss it because as one gets older, regular coffee and even certain types of tea, will interfere with getting a sound sleep at night.

When I was in high school, my parents knew that my friends and I drank occasionally. I'm sure they would have preferred it if we never drank, but they were realistic about it and focused on our safety. They trusted us to NEVER drink and drive or let our friends drink and drive. My parents always stressed that we would never be punished if we called them for a ride - my mom always said she would come get us "no questions asked" and she held true to that.

Many of my friends had parents that were extremely strict about drinking. Instead of taking time to talk to their kids about respecting alcohol, they approached the issue by telling their kids "if you ever touch alcohol you are grounded for six million years." This didn't stop their kids from drinking at all; they would just lie to their parents about where they were and what they were doing.

Freshman year of college (I go to a massive state school), it was blatantly obvious which of my peers were never exposed to alcohol in high school because they tended to be the ones passed out over a toilet by 9 pm or always bragging that they finished a whole handle of vodka in two hours. I'm not at all saying that you should encourage your teens to drink in HS; just make sure they know how to be responsible about it so that if they do choose to drink in college they can avoid dangerous situations.
While that worked well in the 1970s, I'm not sure I'd use it today in any circumstance outside the bedroom.

I'm a Baby Boomer coach and I coach to what I call the Baby Boomer Circle.(tm) It's not surprise to me that this excellent digital Boomer publication receives interest from all ages. Baby Boomers are parents, grandparents, Aunts, Uncles, etc. and they have relationships with children and grandchildren, etc. When Baby Boomers are affected, so to their Boomer Circle may be a well. For instance, a Baby Boomer who has ailing parents and college students has a circle encompassing at least a half century. Although we may not have the extended family manifested as it was in earlier times, the economy and other factors have contributed to a resurgence at some levels of the extended family. Personally, although the reasons that have caused extended family situations, i.e. college grads living at home due to lack of employment, etc.. are not to be desired... the concept of the extended family itself is a very positive one. Even in financial hardship can be found the opportunity for families to have more time together, more communication and hopefully the building of stronger bonds.

Just goes to show that we are all different. My gout is controlled with diet and exercise.....no meds. Any meds taken long term have serious side effects.

Both you and another poster wrote about equalizing effect of the military draft. But, the last time we had one, college students and the those with influential parents managed to avoid it.(as many in the political class can attest) .Viet Nam was largely fought by the have-nots. Perhaps we need another form of compulsory national service, one that could take young people at a formative age, exposing them to each other and the rest of America.
Sorry, but strenuously object to the government forcibly removing people for the purpose of "educating" them whether it be in empathy or anything else.

This is a strong argument for bringing back national service with no exemptions, with the military a voluntary selection within that system. We urgently need to bring back the draft to enhance social equality, acting as a countervailing life experience to restrain the growing shift in the US towards a highly unequal and non upwardly mobile society. Now more and more children of wealthy parents grow up in gated or separated communities and will never interact with lower class kids who live in a different zip code and attend a different set of schools.

We are evolving towards a ruling class hereditary aristocracy lording it over a nation of lower middle class professionals with the majority lower class poorly educated and barely able to get by in a world of robotics running warehouses and factories and industrial farms, where most work requires higher order training and skills.

We should avoid that future.

The October 5 New York Times article on the concerted effort to defund the Affordable Care Act is a must-read. Many, many millions have been spent to shape this effort and it has been supported by a substantial network of conservative political action organizations and, especially gallingly, tax-exempt groups.

The silver lining is that a significant majority of Americans-- roughly 7 of every 10-- remain opposed to defunding the ACA and to promoting this objective by shutting down the federal government or provoking a federal default.

Kudos to the American people who retain a refreshing independence of mind.

After reading many of these posts I'm feeling a bit cynical today, so bear with me.  Today I feel that it's a waste of time to talk sense to the Americans who support these US special forces raids and drone attacks.  It's not that they don't get that the raids don't have any effect on the terrorist organizations other than to help with their recruitment efforts and to multiply the retaliatory attacks against Americans and their allies.  They actually don't care because they don't have to do the fighting and dying - "heroic" others do that for them.  This "war" is a spectator sport that doesn't involve a draft, or even a real military invasion and occupation of a foreign country whose citizens will naturally resist the occupiers to the death - that's what we would do if the roles were reversed.  The War On Terror avoids these pitfalls and can therefore be perpetual since it produces the terror that requires it, and provides vicarious "triumphs" and "victories" without any real risk or sacrifice, as well as electoral platforms for the politicians that promote them and use them to install authoritarian systems of blanket surveillance and revocation of civil liberties at home and abroad.  It's immune to a loss of political support at home because at a time of neoliberal austerity and steady decline in standards of living for ordinary people it provides emotional compensation by channeling discontent into nationalism and cheerleading for American Exceptionalism.

I think the Republicans were expecting Obama to fold because he has done so often in the past. His resistance this time was unexpected. And I think Boehner is still expecting a last minute Obama "compromise."

I've wondered about the history of unions while considered a teacher's strike in my area some decades ago. The district ended the strike by paying a premium wage to substitutes, which have some relevance to the current wages, which are among some of the lowest in the country. In a union everyone gets a vote, and negotiate to some degree for the benefits the receive. A strong union can make it more difficult for those whose responsibility it is to sign the checks. Of course, America is not a labor union. For one thing, there certainly is not any one "owner" to be bargained against, although some might argue the tax payer and others the government. Still, how strong is our Union in a time like this? Are the techniques being used to remove health benefits for a significant cross section of the American community seem in anyway familiar to those who have tried to negotiate for them inside a company? Could the mindset at work be in any way similar to that used to thwart other efforts to collectively bargain? Are the votes at the ballot box being considered in the same way as those in the union hall?
What is the State of our Union?
